I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for subprogram 2 of the Public Sector Enterprises 
Reform Program.1 
 
2.  The  proposed  subprogram  2  of  the  Public  Sector  Enterprises  Reform  Program 
(programmatic approach) will help the Government of Pakistan achieve and sustain reform 
initiatives aimed at enhancing the performance of public sector enterprises (PSEs) by improving 
their  corporate  governance  and  accountability,  and  reducing  their  contingent  liabilities. 
Subprogram 2 will facilitate the creation of fiscal space for critical development expenditures.2  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Finances of PSEs remain weak despite recent reform initiatives. The 183 PSEs 
owned by the government comprise 169 public sector companies (PSCs), 7 development finance 
institutions, and 7 federal authorities. These federal PSEs employ more than 402,543 workers, 
with total assets of PRs10,823 billion ($103 billion) in FY2015. In FY2015, 172 PSEs (94%) 
disclosed their financial statements, with 53 PSEs (29%) reporting losses despite significant 
budget transfers. Total reported aggregate profit was PRs72.98 billion ($0.7 billion), with total 
reported loss of PRs20.35 billion ($0.2 billion). The government’s fiscal risk exposure (combining 
loans and guarantees) was PRs1,472 billion ($14.05 billion) in FY2015.3 Despite recent reform 
initiatives, PSEs continue to rely on significant regular fiscal transfers and sovereign credit 
guarantees to maintain their operations. The power distribution companies (DISCOs) are the 
major recipient of such transfers. Other important beneficiaries include Pakistan International 
Airlines, Pakistan Steel Mill, and Pakistan Railways. In FY2016, the budget allocation to support 
PSEs’ daily operations, including subsidies and other transfers, constituted 59% of overall budget 
allocations to the PSEs. This severely limits the critical capital development expenditures needed 
to improve the efficiency of PSEs. 
 
4.  Fiscal transfers to PSEs jeopardize fiscal sustainability and impede government’s 
development expenditure. High levels of fiscal transfers to PSEs undermine overall fiscal 
stability  and  growth,  which  adversely  affects  critical  investment  on  social  and  economic 
infrastructure, especially when the government has very limited ability to fund such investment 
through borrowings. The government recognizes the importance of reducing the fiscal deficit and 
government borrowings, and imposed severe cuts in budget transfers to PSEs starting in FY2014; 
transfers declined from 3.2% of gross domestic product (GDP) in FY2012 to 1.5% in FY2016,4 
and 0.5% in the first 8 months of FY2017 (Figure 1).5 This budget constraint can help boost the 
accountability  and  efficiency  of  PSEs.  Acknowledging  the  fact  that  reduction  in  budgetary 
transfers is partially attributable to improved performance of some PSEs (including Pakistan 
Railways), hard budget constraint could adversely affect the government’s ability to invest in

modernization has limited the capacity of Pakistan Railways, leading to reduced market share

resources ($375 million in FY2015) for salaries and pension payments alone, severely limiting the 
resources available for urgently needed investments in railway corridors, and upgrading of the

5.  Government’s PSE reform initiatives, sustainability, and constituency building for 
reforms. In mid-FY2013 the government embarked on a PSE reform program to restore PSE 
financial viability and reduce fiscal transfers,7 but soon recognized that a successful PSE reform 
program requires that two prerequisites be met. First, vested stakeholder interests, particularly 
those of PSE employees, require improvements in the operating environment and governance of 
PSEs prior to privatization. Adequate stakeholder consultations and a gradual approach are 
necessary to secure the support of stakeholders for such reforms, which is also true for structural 
reforms that address human resource issues and the affordability of user charges of many PSEs, 
including DISCOs and Pakistan Railways. Second, many reforms require that reform initiatives 
be maintained over a long period to produce the desired results.8 
 
6.  Priority  challenges  and  ADB  assistance.  To  facilitate  the  government’s  reform 
initiatives,  ADB  approved  subprogram  1  of  the  programmatic  approach  in  June  2016.9 
Subprogram 2 continues reforms initiated under subprogram 1. The programmatic approach 
addresses the following three important challenges the government faces while initiating critical 
PSE reforms: 
                                                
6  Despite significant improvements, the operating ratio of Pakistan Railways (total ordinary working expenses as a 
percentage of gross earnings) remains more than 100%. 
7  On 3 October 2013 the Cabinet Committee on Privatization approved a plan to sequence the capital market and pre-
privatization restructuring for 39 PSEs: 11 PSEs for block sales, 25 PSEs for strategic private sector participation, 
and 3 PSEs for restructuring (Pakistan Railways, Pakistan International Airlines, and Pakistan Steel Mills). 
8  Reforms (especially those dealing with politically sensitive issues) are medium- to long-term efforts that require 
continuous support to manage the ownership and institutional capacity factors that impact on reform outcomes. 
Continuity in support for reforms is needed to maintain gains and address weaknesses (ADB. 2009. Special 
Evaluation Study: ADB Support for Public Sector Reforms in the Pacific: Enhance Results through Ownership, 
Capacity, and Continuity. Manila). 
9  ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Programmatic 
Approach and Policy-Based Loan for Public Sector Enterprises Reform Program (Subprogram 1) in Pakistan. Manila.

3 
(i)  The need to coordinate across various government departments to (a) effectively 
implement good corporate governance principles; (b) articulate crucial guiding 
principles, such as transparency and consistency, on issues related to retirement 
benefits; (c) facilitate constituency building for critical reforms in PSEs with the help 
of  an  effective  communications  strategy;10 (d)  monitor  and  evaluate  PSEs’ 
performance; and (e) implement critical structural reforms in some selected PSEs 
to get maximum benefits. 
(ii)  The  need  to  provide  continuing  support  for  some  reforms  initiated  under 
subprogram 1, which by their nature, have a long-term implementation cycle. 
Continued assistance for these reforms would consolidate and sustain gains made 
to improve PSE performance. 
(iii)  The need to plan for and address the substantial adjustment costs associated with 
implementation  of  PSE  reforms.  These  costs  are  a  major  challenge,  given 
Pakistan’s current fiscal context. Identification of reforms and selection of PSEs 
will need to be done very carefully, given the government’s priorities. 
 
7.  Need  for  sequencing of  reforms.  Subprogram  2  is  part  of  an  integrated  solution 
comprising policy-based loans under a programmatic approach, with clear program costs. This 
will  help  ADB  and  the  government  design  and  implement  policy  actions  supporting  the 
government’s reform agenda without excessively straining the government’s budget to finance 
the cost of reforms. Several policy actions are politically sensitive and will require time to prepare, 
including building a constituency for reforms.11 It is critical that reforms are properly identified and 
logically sequenced over two subprograms, under the programmatic approach, if they are to be 
effectively implemented. Some policy actions serve to support other actions included in the 
programmatic approach (e.g., a public awareness campaign), requiring that the various policy 
actions under the overall programmatic approach be carefully timed.  
 
8.  Development coordination. The programmatic approach is part of a well-coordinated 
multidonors  package for  PSE  reforms  in  Pakistan. The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF) 
approved a 3-year extended arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility in September 2013,12 
which concluded in 2016. The World Bank approved four development policy credits in April 2014, 
May 2015, June 2016, and in March 2017. These two programs also support some reforms 
(including privatization) relevant for PSEs in Pakistan. Subprogram 2 complements and carries 
forward similar reforms, especially in the areas of implementing corporate governance rules and 
privatization.  
 
9.  Lessons. The success of PSE reforms is critically dependent on public awareness of the 
reform process and its benefits. Strong government commitment and adequate support from all 
stakeholders are two important prerequisites for a successful PSE reform program; strong 
government commitment is also one of the important prerequisites for successful program lending, 
especially in Pakistan. Thus, setting realistic policy actions is crucial to ensure the government’s

10.  ADB’s value addition.16 Asian Development Bank (ADB) adds significant value to the 
programmatic  approach  by  (i)  facilitating  private  participation  in  PSEs;17 (ii)  improving  the 
targeting of reform-related expenditures and their partial financing; (iii) enhancing coordination 
with development partners in the design and execution of the programmatic approach; (iv) 
providing technical assistance to improve the performance of PSEs such as Pakistan Railways; 
and (v) consolidating policy reforms in the transport and energy sectors, and thereby facilitating 
ongoing and future ADB investments in those sectors. ADB also accommodates the government’s 
ongoing fiscal consolidation by providing affordable least-cost solutions critical to sustaining its 
reform initiatives. 
 
11.  Alignment with ADB’s strategy. Subprogram 2 is part of the 2017 pipeline in the ADB 
Country Operations and Business Plan (COBP), 2017–2019 for Pakistan.18 It will provide critical 
help to the government to address the significant policy challenges and adjustment costs of this 
agenda. It also complements ADB’s public–private partnership (PPP) initiatives in Pakistan and 
the Railways Investment Program, which is under preparation. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact will be reduced net fiscal transfers to PSEs from the federal budget.19 The 
outcome will be improved PSE performance.20

unfunded pensions, and skills training. Under subprogram 2, the government has

D.  Development Financing Needs 
16.  As an integral part of the ongoing fiscal consolidation initiatives—which encompass 
maintaining a moderate debt-to-GDP ratio and building fiscal buffers against adverse shocks—
the government plans to lower the budget deficit (excluding grants) to 4.2% of GDP in FY2017 
from 5.4% in FY2015, mainly through revenue mobilization and expenditure rationalization. 
However, given the sluggish nature of revenue improvements over the short to medium term, the 
burden  of  fiscal  consolidation  will  primarily  fall  on  expenditure  rationalization,  especially 
development expenditures. As a result, it will be difficult to maintain, if not augment, the past trend 
of  development  expenditures  and  development  loans  (primarily  for  investment  to  augment 
capacity) for PSEs (including Pakistan Railways). This is a clear illustration of a hard budget 
constraint and its impact on development financing, given the rigidity in nondiscretionary recurrent 
expenditures  (salary,  pensions,  and  interest).  The  government’s  support  for  productive 
investments in PSEs needs to be revived, and will be supported under the program. 
 
17.  It will also be difficult for the government to incur additional costs to carry out PSE reforms, 
unless expenditures on specific items are targeted and partly financed by the government’s 
development  partners.  Strong  expenditure  rationalization  efforts  will  be  needed  to  enable 
additional reform-related expenditures, to the extent these are reflected in the federal budget, 
within the stipulated fiscal deficit targets. 
 
18.   Unfunded pension liability is a risk to a company's financial condition due to underfunding 
of defined benefit pension plan. Unfunded pensions and other retirement benefits are major 
constraints for timely privatization (or strategic sale of shares) of DISCOs. Unless addressed 
efficiently, these will have an adverse impact on the government’s divestment income from 
privatization. Therefore, it is proposed that the government will help creating Retirement Cost 
Funds and encourage operationalization of these Funds.  Putting some of these items together 
and combining them with the government’s commitment to reduce the fiscal deficit-to-GDP ratio, 
development financing needs of approximately $897 million over the entire program period (2016–
2018) is foreseen.34 The programmatic approach is expected to finance nearly 67% of this 
development financing requirement. Thus, the programmatic approach will help the government 
to pursue, without breaching the fiscal targets, its macroeconomic reform agenda, including PSE 
reforms.  
 
19.   The government has requested a concessional loan of $300 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 2. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace period of 5 years; an interest rate of 2% per year during the grace period and thereafter; 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
                                                
33 Out of the 16 policy actions, 15 policy actions have already been complied with. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) is 
in the process of finalizing its interim report on departmental restructuring and workforce rationalization and will 
approve the key recommendations of this interim report before the Board consideration of subprogram 2. 
34 Based on detailed discussions with the government officials, it was agreed to support five major costs of reforms 
under the programmatic approach (combining both Subprogram 1 and Subprogram 2): (i) support for revival of the 
government support to PSEs for investment to augment capacity; (ii) funding of a retirement benefit fund to manage 
huge unfunded pensions and other retirement liabilities of workers, (iii) cost of vocational and other trainings, and (iv) 
communication cost. To facilitate private investment (strategic sales through IPOs), MOF has also incurred additional 
cost by providing financial assistance to selected DISCOs to settle the receivables in their balance sheets.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF), through its Finance Division, will continue to be the 
executing agency for subprogram 2. The program management unit (PMU) established under 
subprogram 1 will be responsible for the overall coordination and reporting on implementation 
arrangements. The Finance Division, MOR, Pakistan Railways, the Privatization Commission, 
and SECP will be the implementing agencies. 
 
21.  The PMU will assist the implementing agencies in the implementation of subprogram 2, 
and will conduct regular consultations to ensure timely completion of all policy actions. A senior 
government official will serve as the program director. The PMU will be responsible for (i) 
coordinating  and  monitoring  subprogram  2,  including  the  policy  actions;  (ii)  preparing  and 
submitting all required reports to the Finance Division and ADB; and (iii) submitting the necessary 
statements and reports to ADB. 
 
22.  The implementation period for subprogram 2 is from 30 June 2017 to 30 June 2018. The 
proceeds of the loan will be disbursed upon fulfillment of the policy actions, to the satisfaction of 
ADB, in accordance with (i) ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2015, as amended from time 
to time), and (ii) simplified disbursement procedures for program loans.35 ADB will monitor the 
implementation of subprogram 2 through periodic progress reports and will field regular missions 
to confirm fulfillment of the policy actions.  
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
23.  The beneficiaries will primarily be the domestic, industrial, agricultural, and commercial 
clients of public goods and services provided by PSEs, which will deliver improved services in a 
cost-effective manner. Taxpayers and recipients of government services will indirectly benefit 
from the reduced fiscal costs of PSEs. PSE staff are expected to benefit from a consistent and 
fair approach to retirement benefits, as set out in the program. 
 
A.  Economic 
24.  The beneficiaries of subprogram 2 will be the people of Pakistan, who will directly benefit 
from the improved delivery of services, especially in the areas of power and transportation. 
Moreover, subprogram 2 will facilitate government fiscal investments in social and economic 
infrastructure,  which  will  result  in  improved  health  and  education  services  and  economic 
opportunities. In addition, subprogram 2 will stimulate private sector activity by partly substituting 
government service commitments. The beneficial effect on federal finances will originate primarily 
from three sources: non-debt capital receipts (disinvestment income), reduced fiscal transfers, 
and higher dividend income. In addition, the government will reduce its contingent liabilities once 
pensions and related retirement liabilities are funded appropriately.36 
 
B.  Governance 
25.  Subprogram 2 has many policy actions that will promote good governance in public 
service delivery. Improving internal audit, and accounting practices of Pakistan Railways are 
covered under subprogram 2. Several initiatives will be introduced under the programmatic 
approach to (i) improve internal audit based on risk analysis, (ii) strengthen transparency in 
                                                
35 ADB. 1998. Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila (R50-
98). 
36 Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
procurements, and (ii) introduce financial statements that comply with International Financial 
Reporting Standards starting in FY2018.  
 
26.  Many PSEs do not follow the SECP’s Public Sector Companies (Corporate Governance) 
Rules, 2013. The program has introduced relevant policy actions to facilitate compliance with 
these rules, and subprogram 2 will ensure that all PSEs are covered under them. 
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, including the Finance Division of the MOF. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
28.  Subprogram 2 has a positive impact on poverty reduction and social issues, through two 
interlinked  mechanisms.  First,  support  for  augmenting  and  sustaining  the  government’s 
development financing will substantially impact human and income poverty. Second, many 
reforms will help the government reduce the economic and fiscal costs that Pakistan’s PSEs 
impose  on  consumers,  taxpayers,  and  beneficiaries  of  social  services.  Subprogram  2  will 
maximize the benefits that private management and improved corporate and sector governance 
can bring to the economic efficiency and financial feasibility of PSEs. These changes are 
expected to improve access to basic services such as electricity (through power distribution 
companies) and public transportation (through railways). The PSEs to be restructured and 
privatized may decrease their demand for low-skilled labor in the future. The programmatic 
approach will therefore facilitate critical initiatives, through the targeted policy actions, to address 
labor issues, particularly related to retirement benefits and alternative skills development.37 The 
reform  measures  under  subprogram  2  will  in  turn  help  free  government  fiscal  resources, 
facilitating higher public spending on social sectors, particularly health, education, and social 
protection. Subprogram 2 has important gender impacts. Policy measures will support gender 
inclusiveness by ensuring mandatory representation of women on PSE boards, and mandate 
regular reporting of gender statistics of PSE boards.38 The mandatory presence of at least one 
female member on each PSE board under the approved change in the Companies Bill 2017 will 
increase women’s representation to at least 15% from the current low level of 4% (commercial 
PSCs) and 3% (noncommercial PSCs). 
 
D.  Safeguards 
29.  Given  the  nature  of  subprogram  2,  all  three  safeguard  categories  (environment, 
involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples)  are  categorized  as  C.  Safeguards  due 
diligence shows policy actions associated with subprogram 2 will not result in any involuntary 
resettlement or environmental impacts. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
30.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in the table and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.39 The integrated benefits and impacts are 
expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
                                                
37 ADB is also proposing skills development programs through loan and TA projects in Pakistan.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITION 
31.  The government and MOF have assured ADB that implementation of subprogram 2 shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the loan documents. 
 
32.  It is a condition of loan effectiveness that ADB is satisfied that all policy actions set out in 
the policy matrix in respect of subprogram 2 have been fully complied with.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $300,000,000 to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for subprogram 2 of the Public Sector 
Enterprises Reform Program, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional terms, with 
an interest charge at the rate of 2% per year during the grace period and thereafter; for a term of 
25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
